content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Nine experienced runners participated in a well-designed controlled experiment to investigate whether listening to music while running will allow a runner to run faster. On each of two consecutive Saturdays, the runners ran on a track until they completed <math alttext="3.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles. Researchers recorded the time, in seconds, for each runner to complete <math alttext="3.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles. On one day the runners listened to music while running, and on the other day the runners did not listen to music. For each runner, a coin was flipped to determine on which day, the first or second, music was used. The following dotplot shows the differences in running times (no music minus music) for the <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>9</mn></math> runners. (a) For the investigation, what does the positive difference of <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> indicate?

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Nine experienced runners participated in a well-designed controlled experiment to investigate whether listening to music while running will allow a runner to run faster. On each of two consecutive Saturdays, the runners ran on a track until they completed <math alttext="3.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles. Researchers recorded the time, in seconds, for each runner to complete <math alttext="3.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles. On one day the runners listened to music while running, and on the other day the runners did not listen to music. For each runner, a coin was flipped to determine on which day, the first or second, music was used. The following dotplot shows the differences in running times (no music minus music) for the <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>9</mn></math> runners. (a) For the investigation, what does the positive difference of <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> indicate?

If listening to music has no effect on running time, then running time is equally likely to be greater for either condition, music or no music. Under that assumption, the probability that the difference (no music minus music) will be positive for any particular runner is <math alttext="p equals 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the number of runners out of <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runners who have a positive difference (no music minus music) in running time.(b) Assume that the differences in running times are independent of one another. From the sample of <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runners, <math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> have a positive difference (no music minus music).(i) If listening to music has no effect on running time, what is the probability that among <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></math> runners, <math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> or more runners will have a positive difference in running times? Show your work.

(ii) Based on your answer in part (b-i), is it reasonable to believe that runners tend to have longer running times while not listening to music? Explain your answer without performing an inference procedure.

In part (b-ii), only the signs of the differences (positive or negative), not the magnitudes, are used. An alternative method that takes into account both the sign and the magnitude of the differences in running times is based on the sum, <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, of ranks corresponding to positive differences. For the experiment described above, <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is computed by first ordering the absolute values of the nine differences in times from smallest to largest. Next, ranks are computed for the absolute values of the differences with rank <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> corresponding to the smallest absolute value, rank <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> corresponding to the second smallest absolute value, up to rank <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> corresponding to the largest absolute value. Finally, the value of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math> is computed by summing only the values of the ranks corresponding to positive differences; the values of the ranks corresponding to negative differences are not included in the sum. The following table displays the differences and the ranks of the absolute values of the differences for the nine runners who participated in the experiment, where rank <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> indicates the smallest absolute value and rank <math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>9</mn></math> indicates the largest absolute value.Differences<math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="negative 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="negative 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="44" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>44</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="45" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="52" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>52</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="53" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>53</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>Ranks of absolute values of the differences<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>(c) Determine the value of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.A simulation was carried out to investigate the sampling distribution of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The value of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math> was calculated for each of <math alttext="1,000" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></math> trials of the simulation, where each trial was simulated under the assumption that listening to music has no effect on running time. The results are shown in the dotplot.
(d) Based on the simulation results and your response to part (c), is it reasonable to conclude that not listening to music tends to result in longer running times? Justify your conclusion.

topic.text: 1.6: Describing the Distribution of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Describe data presented numerically or graphically.
